questions.question_text_1: THIS IS QUESTION PAPER FOR THE SUBJECT "DEGREE LEVEL : AI: SEARCH METHODS FOR PROBLEM SOLVING (COMPUTER BASED EXAM)" ARE YOU SURE YOU HAVE TO WRITE EXAM FOR THIS SUBJECT? CROSS CHECK YOUR HALL TICKET TO CONFIRM THE SUBJECTS TO BE WRITTEN. (IF IT IS NOT THE CORRECT SUBJECT, PLS CHECK THE SECTION AT THE TOP FOR THE SUBJECTS REGISTERED BY YOU)

options.option_text: Printed graph sheets were provided on time.
Printed graph sheets were provided late.
Printed graph sheets were not provided.
I did not use graph sheets.

questions.question_text_1: SEARCH The figure shows a map with several locations on a grid where each tile is 1x1 in size. The locations are at grid points and are connected by two way edges (roads), where each edge has a cost that is the same in both directions. Observe that the edge costs are not necessarily proportional to the coordinate based distance estimates. The start node is S and the goal node is G, the MoveGen function returns neighbours in alphabetical order. Use Manhattan distance as the heuristic function. Tie-breaker: when several nodes have the same best cost, use alphabetical order to break ties.
questions.question_text_2: SEARCH The figure shows a map with several locations on a grid where each tile is 1x1 in size. The locations are at grid points and are connected by two way edges (roads), where each edge has a cost that is the same in both directions. Observe that the edge costs are not necessarily proportional to the coordinate based distance estimates. The start node is S and the goal node is G, the MoveGen function returns neighbours in alphabetical order. Use Manhattan distance as the heuristic function. Tie-breaker: when several nodes have the same best cost, use alphabetical order to break ties. Emulate A*, WA* and Branch-and-Bound on the given map, then answer the subquestions.

questions.question_text_1:
TSP

The distance matrix for 6 cities are provided below. For each city the distances to other cities are listed in ascending order. For example, the distance from A to D is 38, and from A to E is 46, and so on.
questions.question_text_2: TSP The distance matrix for 6 cities are provided below. For each city the distances to other cities are listed in ascending order. For example, the distance from A to D is 38, and from A to E is 46, and so on. Solve the sub-questions using the TSP Branch-and-Bound algorithm. Attention: Infer as much as possible (and as early as possible) about the permanent segments in the partial solutions. A segment is a two-way edge between two cities.
question_texts:
TSP

The distance matrix for 6 cities are provided below. For each city the distances to other cities are listed in ascending order. For example, the distance from A to D is 38, and from A to E is 46, and so on.

TSP The distance matrix for 6 cities are provided below. For each city the distances to other cities are listed in ascending order. For example, the distance from A to D is 38, and from A to E is 46, and so on. Solve the sub-questions using the TSP Branch-and-Bound algorithm. Attention: Infer as much as possible (and as early as possible) about the permanent segments in the partial solutions. A segment is a two-way edge between two cities.

The distance matrix for 6 cities are provided below. For each city the distances to other cities are listed in ascending order. For example, the distance from A to D is 38, and from A to E is 46, and so on.
parent_question.question_text_2: TSP The distance matrix for 6 cities are provided below. For each city the distances to other cities are listed in ascending order. For example, the distance from A to D is 38, and from A to E is 46, and so on. Solve the sub-questions using the TSP Branch-and-Bound algorithm. Attention: Infer as much as possible (and as early as possible) about the permanent segments in the partial solutions. A segment is a two-way edge between two cities.
question_texts:
TSP

The distance matrix for 6 cities are provided below. For each city the distances to other cities are listed in ascending order. For example, the distance from A to D is 38, and from A to E is 46, and so on.

TSP The distance matrix for 6 cities are provided below. For each city the distances to other cities are listed in ascending order. For example, the distance from A to D is 38, and from A to E is 46, and so on. Solve the sub-questions using the TSP Branch-and-Bound algorithm. Attention: Infer as much as possible (and as early as possible) about the permanent segments in the partial solutions. A segment is a two-way edge between two cities.

questions.question_text_1: AUTOMATED PLANNING The domain description of a blocks-world with a single one-armed robot is provided below. Note: this is the same domain description used in the weekly assignments.
questions.question_text_2: AUTOMATED PLANNING The domain description of a blocks-world with a single one-armed robot is provided below. Note: this is the same domain description used in the weekly assignments. Tie-breaker: When actions are chosen non-deterministically, choose actions that lead to a plan. Throw away the actions that lead to deadends and cycles. Tie-breaker: Treat the goal description, preconditions and effects as lists that are accessed from left to right. When the elements in a list are pushed one by one to a stack, the last element in the list will be at the top of the stack. It has the effect of reversing the list. A planning problem is given below, find a plan using the operators and predicates defined in the blocks-world domain.

A planning problem is given below, find a plan using the operators and predicates defined in the blocks-world domain. Based on the above data, answer the given subquestions.

Tie-breaker: When actions are chosen non-deterministically, choose actions that lead to a plan. Throw away the actions that lead to deadends and cycles. Tie-breaker: Treat the goal description, preconditions and effects as lists that are accessed from left to right. When the elements in a list are pushed one by one to a stack, the last element in the list will be at the top of the stack. It has the effect of reversing the list. props.summary:
### Summary of Core Topics, Concepts, Principles, and Equations

#### 1. Search Algorithms
**Core Topics:**
- A* Search Algorithm
- Weighted A* (WA*) Search Algorithm
- Branch-and-Bound Algorithm
- Heuristic Functions
- Tie-breaking Rules

**Concepts and Principles:**
- **A* Search Algorithm:** Uses a combination of the cost to reach a node and a heuristic estimate of the cost to reach the goal.
- **Weighted A* (WA*) Search Algorithm:** A variant of A* where the heuristic function is weighted to balance between exploration and exploitation.
- **Branch-and-Bound Algorithm:** A systematic method for solving optimization problems by dividing them into smaller subproblems.
- **Heuristic Functions:** Functions that estimate the cost from a given state to the goal state. The Manhattan distance is a common heuristic for grid-based problems.
- **Tie-breaking Rules:** When multiple nodes have the same cost, use alphabetical order to break ties.

**Equations:**
- **A* Algorithm:** \( f(n) = g(n) + h(n) \)
  - \( g(n) \): Cost from the start node to node \( n \)
  - \( h(n) \): Heuristic estimate of the cost from node \( n \) to the goal
- **Manhattan Distance:** \( h(n) = |x_n - x_g| + |y_n - y_g| \)
  - \( (x_n, y_n) \): Coordinates of node \( n \)
  - \( (x_g, y_g) \): Coordinates of the goal node

#### 2. Traveling Salesman Problem (TSP)
**Core Topics:**
- TSP Branch-and-Bound Algorithm
- Lower Bound Calculation
- Permanent Segments
- Tour Cost Calculation

**Concepts and Principles:**
- **TSP Branch-and-Bound Algorithm:** A method for solving the TSP by systematically exploring possible tours and eliminating suboptimal ones.
- **Lower Bound Calculation:** Estimating the minimum possible cost of a tour to prune the search tree.
- **Permanent Segments:** Edges that are guaranteed to be part of the optimal tour.
- **Tour Cost Calculation:** Summing the distances of the edges in a tour to determine its total cost.

**Equations:**
- **Lower Bound Calculation:** Sum of the minimum distances for each city to its nearest neighbors.
- **Tour Cost Calculation:** \( \text{Cost} = \sum_{i=1}^{n} d(c_i, c_{i+1}) \)
  - \( d(c_i, c_{i+1}) \): Distance between city \( c_i \) and city \( c_{i+1} \)

#### 3. Game Trees and Algorithms
**Core Topics:**
- Game Tree Evaluation
- Alpha-Beta Pruning
- SSS* Algorithm
- Horizon Nodes

**Concepts and Principles:**
- **Game Tree Evaluation:** Evaluating the outcome of a game tree based on the evaluations of horizon nodes.
- **Alpha-Beta Pruning:** A search algorithm that reduces the number of nodes evaluated in the search tree.
- **SSS* Algorithm:** A selective search algorithm that focuses on the most promising nodes.
- **Horizon Nodes:** Nodes at the deepest level of the game tree that carry evaluations.

**Equations:**
- **Alpha-Beta Pruning:** Uses alpha and beta values to prune branches that cannot affect the final decision.
- **SSS* Algorithm:** Uses a selective search strategy to focus on the most promising nodes.

#### 4. Automated Planning
**Core Topics:**
- Planning Domain Description
- Goal Stack Planning
- Applicable and Relevant Actions
- Subgoal Ordering

**Concepts and Principles:**
- **Planning Domain Description:** Defines the predicates and operators for a planning problem.
- **Goal Stack Planning:** A planning algorithm that uses a stack to manage subgoals.
- **Applicable Actions:** Actions that can be executed in the current state.
- **Relevant Actions:** Actions that contribute to achieving the goal.
- **Subgoal Ordering:** Ordering subgoals to efficiently achieve the main goal.

**Equations:**
- **Goal Stack Planning:** Uses a stack to manage subgoals and applies actions to achieve them.
- **Subgoal Ordering:** Orders subgoals based on their relevance and applicability.

### Knowledge Graph 

```mermaid
graph TD;
    A[Search Algorithms] --> B[A* Search Algorithm];
    A --> C[Weighted A* Search Algorithm];
    A --> D[Branch-and-Bound Algorithm];
    A --> E[Heuristic Functions];
    A --> F[Tie-breaking Rules];

    G[Traveling Salesman Problem] --> H[TSP Branch-and-Bound Algorithm];
    G --> I[Lower Bound Calculation];
    G --> J[Permanent Segments];
    G --> K[Tour Cost Calculation];

    L[Game Trees and Algorithms] --> M[Game Tree Evaluation];
    L --> N[Alpha-Beta Pruning];
    L --> O[SSS* Algorithm];
    L --> P[Horizon Nodes];

    Q[Automated Planning] --> R[Planning Domain Description];
    Q --> S[Goal Stack Planning];
    Q --> T[Applicable Actions];
    Q --> U[Relevant Actions];
    Q --> V[Subgoal Ordering];
```

```mermaid
graph TD;
    B --> W[f(n) = g(n) + h(n)];
    B --> X[Manhattan Distance];

    H --> Y[Lower Bound Calculation];
    H --> Z[Tour Cost Calculation];

    N --> AA[Alpha and Beta Values];
    O --> AB[Selective Search Strategy];

    S --> AC[Stack Management];
    V --> AD[Subgoal Ordering];
```

These graphs visually map the relationships between the core topics, concepts, and equations essential for the exam.
